title: Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Wood Walking Route

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Blower's Brook
images.caption: Blower's Brook. This small watercourse flows into the Sence, thence the Anker, thence the Tame, and ultimately the Trent and Humber into the North Sea.

images.title: RobinLeicester, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Flagship Diamond Wood, Leicestershire - taken in spring 2012 just before the planting. The recently made lake occupies the site of an open cast coal mine.

images.title: Philip Jeffrey / Bluebells in Holy Rood churchyard
images.caption: Holy Trinity (NOT Holy Rood) parish church, Normanton-le-Heath, Leicestershire, seen from the east with bluebells in bloom

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Bridleway to Normanton Lane
images.caption: Bridleway to Normanton Lane. Heading south along the edge of this large field. A small area of uncultivated land on the left contains a small pond.

images.title: cris sloan / No Doubt
images.caption: Dog at the corner of a field to the east of Nomanton Le Heath.

images.title: The Main Street of Normanton le Heath by Mat Fascione, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Main Street of Normanton le Heath

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Open cast coal mine near Ravenstone
images.caption: Open cast coal mine near Ravenstone. Looking north-east towards Coalville in the distance. At the bottom of this field on the left is the Longmoor open cast coal mine. Lots of controversy here as the Government overruled the local council, who had refused planning permission for UK Coal on this greenfield site.

images.title: Information board at the Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Wood by Mat Fascione, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Information board and map at the Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Wood

description: This walk explores the Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Wood near Normanton Le Heath in the National Forest. These peaceful Leicestershire woods were planted in 2012 to celebrate the Queen's Diamond Jubilee. The site is criss crossed with a number of pleasant waymarked footpaths taking you to a picturesque lake and the Bowers Brook on the eastern edge. You can start your walk from the free car park on Heather Lane on the western side of the woods. Then head east towards the lake where you can see a variety of water loving wildlife. Birds of note include little grebes, tufter ducks, skylarks, buzzards and hen harrier. The woods are located right next to the lovely Sence Valley Forest Park so it's easy to extend your outing if you have time. Just follow a bridletrack south east for about half a mile and you will come to the site. There's a series of pretty lakes and some more fine walking and cycling trails here. The Kelham Bridge Nature Reserve can also be found just a mile or so to the east. You can reach it by following the National Forest Way, a long distance trail which explores some of the highlights of the National Forest area.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: As you'd imagine the woodland paths are ideal for a dog walk. You'll probably see other owners on a fine day.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To continue your walking in the area pick up the Coalville Walk and enjoy some waterside trails at Thornton Reservoir and a climb to the viewpoint at nearby Bardon Hill.

display_address: Heather Lane, Normanton Le Heath, North West Leicestershire, Leicestershire, England, LE67 2TD, United Kingdom
